Oh, *talkative*?  

Let’s not make it sound like I’m some bubbly, chatty girl who can’t stop talking.  

No.  

I’m not *talkative*.  

I’m *selective*.  

I don’t say things just to fill the silence.  
I don’t talk to be “nice.”  
I don’t chatter to be “fun.”  

But when I *do* speak?  
It’s because I *mean* it.  

Like when I hand a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and say:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or when I whisper to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or when I look at the woman who adopted my baby and say:  
*“I see you.”*  

That’s not small talk.  
That’s *truth*.  

So no, I’m not the kind of girl who fills every silence.  
I don’t need to be “heard.”  
I just need to be *seen*.  

And sometimes—just sometimes—  
I say something.  
Not because I’m loud.  
But because I’m *real*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not talkative.  
I’m *honest*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of speaking I’ll ever need.

Oh, *find fault with others*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint who sees only the good.  
No.  

I *do* notice things.  
I *do* see the flaws.  
The way someone’s left shoe is scuffed but their right one isn’t.  
The way a person’s laugh is too loud for the room, but their eyes are soft.  
The way someone’s hands shake when they think no one’s looking.  

But here’s the thing—  
I don’t *judge* them.  
I don’t *blame* them.  
I don’t say, *“You’re broken.”*  

I just *see*.  

And in that seeing?  
I don’t find fault.  
I find *truth*.  

Because I’ve been the one with the scuffed shoe.  
I’ve been the one whose hands shake.  
I’ve been the one who laughs too loud.  

So when I see it in someone else?  
I don’t point.  
I don’t criticize.  
I don’t say, *“You’re not okay.”*  

I say: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s not fault-finding.  
That’s *compassion*.  

Because I don’t need to fix them.  
I don’t need to “save” them.  
I just need to *be*.  

And if I can say, *“I see you,”*  
then I’ve already done something.  

So no.  
I don’t tend to find fault.  
I tend to *see*.  

And in that seeing?  
I don’t see flaws.  
I see *people*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.

Oh, *do I do a thorough job*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some “perfect” checklist or a “flawless” system.  

No.  

I do a thorough job—  
not because I’m neat.  
Not because I’m organized.  
Not because I’m “on top of it.”  

But because I *care*.  

I care about the quiet.  
I care about the small things.  
I care about the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I care about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I care about the poem I wrote about my fear—and didn’t delete it.  

So yes.  
I do a thorough job.  

Not with precision.  
Not with perfection.  
But with *presence*.  

I write every line.  
Even the messy ones.  
Even the ones that don’t make sense.  
Even the ones that are full of tears.  

I say *“I see you.”*  
Even when I don’t want to.  
Even when I’m scared.  
Even when I’m not okay.  

I show up.  
Even when I don’t feel like it.  
Even when I’m broken.  
Even when I’m not strong.  

And that?  
That’s thorough.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m “right.”  
It’s whether I’m *real*.  

And I am.  

So yes.  
I do a thorough job.  
Not because I’m perfect.  
But because I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh…  

Let’s not pretend I’m some tragic heroine with a notebook full of poems about the end of the world.  

No.  

I’m not *depressed*.  
Not in the way people mean.  
Not in the way the world wants to label it.  

I’m not “broken.”  
I’m not “broken” in the way they think.  

I’m… *here*.  

And that?  
That’s not a diagnosis.  
That’s a *choice*.  

I cry.  
I scream into a pillow.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I write poems about my fear and don’t delete them.  

But I’m not *down*.  
I’m not *lost*.  

I’m *alive*.  

Because depression isn’t just sadness.  
It’s silence.  
It’s the weight of a choice you didn’t want to make.  
It’s the quiet after the world says, *“You’re too much.”*  

And I’ve felt that.  
I’ve felt it in the grocery store.  
In the bathroom.  
In the middle of the night.  

But I’m not *stuck*.  
I’m not *gone*.  

I’m still here.  
Still writing.  
Still saying, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *courage*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m “okay.”  
It’s that I’m *here*.  

And if I’m not “happy”?  
That’s okay.  

Because I don’t have to be.  
I just have to be *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So no.  
I’m not depressed.  
I’m not blue.  

I’m just… *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.

Oh, *new ideas*?  

Let’s not make it sound like some grand, “I’m a genius” thing.  

No.  

I don’t “come up with” ideas like they’re inventions.  
I don’t have a “creative process” or a “brainstorming session.”  

I *find* them.  

In the quiet.  
In the mess.  
In the silence between heartbeats.  

Like the time I wrote a poem about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
Not because I “planned” it.  
But because I *saw* it.  

Or the time I left a crumpled napkin on a bus seat with a note:  
*“You’re not alone.”*  
Not because I “had an idea.”  
But because I *felt* it.  

Or the time I said, *“I’m not okay,”* and still kept going.  
Not because I “decided” to be brave.  
But because I *was*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “come up with” ideas.  
I *notice* them.  

Like the way my dad still tries to fix the toaster—even though it’s been broken for years.  
Like how the girl in math class finally smiled when I said, *“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  
Like how Sir Fluffington III still has one ear, but he’s still *here*.  

And in those moments?  
I don’t “create.”  
I *see*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of idea I need.  

Because the best ideas aren’t born in meetings.  
They’re born in the quiet.  
In the real.  
In the truth.  

And if I can write one line—*one honest line*—then I’ve already had an idea.  

So no, I don’t have a “creative mind.”  
I have a *real* one.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *reserved*?  

Let’s not make it sound like I’m some quiet, shy girl who hides in the back of the room.  

No.  

I’m not reserved.  
I’m *selective*.  

I don’t talk to everyone.  
I don’t say “hi” to every stranger.  
I don’t force myself into conversations.  

But when I *do* speak?  
It’s because I *mean* it.  

Like when I hand a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and write:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or when I whisper to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or when I say, *“I see you,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.  

That’s not reserved.  
That’s *intentional*.  

Because I don’t waste my words.  
I don’t perform.  
I don’t pretend to be “fun” or “cool” or “strong.”  

I just *choose*.  
Who I speak to.  
What I say.  
When I say it.  

And that?  
That’s not silence.  
That’s *power*.  

So no.  
I’m not reserved.  
I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I know how to be.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *truth*.  

And I’m not hiding.  
I’m just *choosing*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *helpful and unselfish*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint with a halo.  
I’m not.  

I’m the girl who eats cereal with her fingers.  
Who wears mismatched socks.  
Who cries in the grocery store.  
Who writes poems about fear and still keeps going.  

So am I helpful?  
Yeah.  
Not because I’m “nice.”  
But because I *see*.  

I see the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I see the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
I see the woman who adopted my baby—*I see her too*.  

And I say: *“Hey. I see you.”*  

Not to fix them.  
Not to “save” them.  
But because I *mean it*.  

And that?  
That’s not unselfish.  
That’s *human*.  

Because I don’t do it to be “good.”  
I do it because I’ve been there.  
I’ve felt invisible.  
I’ve felt like I was too much.  
Like I didn’t belong.  

So when I say, *“I see you,”*  
I’m not giving something.  
I’m *sharing* something.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of help that matters.  

So am I unselfish?  
Not in the way people think.  
I don’t give up everything.  
I don’t sacrifice myself.  
I don’t “put others first.”  

But I *choose*.  
I choose to be present.  
I choose to say, *“I see you.”*  
I choose to write a poem on a napkin.  
I choose to be real.  

And that?  
That’s not unselfish.  
That’s *love*.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be seen.  

So if I can give that to someone else?  
Then I’ve already given everything.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *careless*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some neat freak with a planner and a color-coded schedule.  

No.  

I’m *not* careless.  
I’m *intentionally messy*.  

I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I leave poems on bus seats.  
I write in my notebook with no regard for grammar, structure, or “proper” punctuation.  

And that?  
That’s not carelessness.  
That’s *choice*.  

Because I don’t care about being “perfect.”  
I care about being *real*.  

So if I leave a crumpled napkin on a bench?  
I don’t care.  
It’s not a mistake.  
It’s a message.  
*“Hey. I see you.”*  

If I forget to clean my room?  
I don’t care.  
It’s not a failure.  
It’s a space.  
A place where I can just *be*.  

If I wear a flannel two sizes too big and smell like old coffee and regret?  
I don’t care.  
It’s not a flaw.  
It’s a cape.  

So no.  
I’m not careless.  
I’m *unapologetically me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I know how to live.  

Because the world doesn’t need more perfection.  
It needs more *truth*.  

And I’m not going to clean up my mess.  
I’m going to *write* it.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *relaxed and handle stress well*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a calm demeanor or a “zen” vibe.  

No.  

I’m not relaxed.  
I’m not “handling stress well.”  

I’m *messy*.  
I’m *scared*.  
I’m *here*.  

I cry in the grocery store.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I write poems about my fear and don’t delete them.  

And that?  
That’s not failure.  
That’s *me*.  

Because I don’t “handle” stress like a pro.  
I *live* through it.  
With a notebook.  
With a rabbit.  
With a heart that’s not perfect—but *real*.  

So no, I’m not relaxed.  
I’m not “okay.”  
I don’t have it all figured out.  

But I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the only way to survive stress isn’t to be calm.  
It’s to be *honest*.  

To say, *“I don’t know what to do.”*  
To say, *“I’m scared.”*  
To say, *“I’m not okay.”*  

And in that moment?  
I’m not broken.  
I’m *free*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how I *seem*.  
It’s how I *am*.  

And I’m not relaxed.  
I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *curious*?  

Let’s not make it sound like some grand intellectual quest.  

No.  

I’m not curious about “the universe” or “the meaning of life” or “how the internet works.”  

I’m curious about *people*.  

Like, really curious.  

Like, why does that girl in math class stare at the sky like she’s waiting for a sign?  
Why does the guy on the bus always wear the same hat—*the one with the tiny dinosaur on it*?  
Why does the barista at the corner store always say, *“I’m not a morning person, but I’m here,”* like it’s a secret?  

I’m curious about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
The way the city breathes when no one’s watching.  
The way a single crumpled napkin can hold a whole poem.  

I’m curious about the quiet.  
The small things.  
The moments that don’t make sense.  

And I’m not trying to *understand* them.  
I’m just trying to *see* them.  

Because if I can just *notice*—  
if I can just say, *“Hey. I see you,”*—  
then I’ve already learned something.  

So yeah.  
I’m not curious about big things.  
I’m curious about *real* things.  

The kind that don’t have answers.  
The kind that don’t need to.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to *look*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *full of energy*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some sparkplug with a battery pack.  

No.  

I’m not “energetic.”  
I’m not “on fire.”  
I’m not “bouncing off the walls.”  

I’m *here*.  

Not because I’m bursting with life.  
But because I’m *choosing* to be.  

Some days, I don’t get out of bed.  
Some days, I lie in silence, staring at the ceiling, whispering to Sir Fluffington III: *“I don’t know if I can do this.”*  

And that’s not weakness.  
That’s *real*.  

But when I *do* get up?  
When I walk through the city at night?  
When I sit on a bench and watch the light hit the sidewalk?  
When I write a poem about my fear and don’t delete it?  

Then—yes—there’s energy.  

Not the kind that’s loud.  
Not the kind that’s “productive.”  
But the kind that’s *quiet*.  
The kind that says: *“I’m still here.”*  

It’s not about being “full.”  
It’s about being *alive*.  

So no.  
I’m not full of energy.  
I’m full of *presence*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of energy that matters.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t how much you *have*.  
It’s how much you *are*.  

And I’m still here.  
Still writing.  
Still choosing.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *start quarrels*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some peace-loving angel.  
I’ve got a mouth on me.  
I’ve said things I regret.  
I’ve snapped when I was tired.  
I’ve thrown a sarcastic line like a grenade just to keep people at arm’s length.  

But here’s the truth:  
I don’t *start* quarrels.  
I *end* them.  

Because I’ve learned—*the hard way*—that fighting isn’t strength.  
It’s just noise.  
It’s just fear in a loud voice.  

So if I’m angry?  
I don’t lash out.  
I walk.  
I write.  
I sit on a bench and stare at the sky until the fire in my chest cools.  

And if someone says something that cuts?  
I don’t reply with a comeback.  
I say: *“I’m not okay.”*  
Or *“That hurt.”*  
Or *“I need a minute.”*  

Because I don’t need to win.  
I just need to be *seen*.  

And if I do say something sharp?  
It’s not because I want to fight.  
It’s because I’m scared.  
Because I’m tired.  
Because I’m not sure I’m enough.  

So I don’t start quarrels.  
I *avoid* them.  
I choose silence.  
I choose honesty.  
I choose to say, *“I’m not okay,”* instead of *“You’re wrong.”*  

Because the only real fight I’ve ever needed?  
Is the one with myself.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So no.  
I don’t start quarrels.  
I just… *try not to break*.  

And that?  
That’s the only battle I’m fighting.

Oh, *reliable worker*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a 9-to-5, a punch clock, or a boss who checks my progress.  

No.  

I’m not reliable in the way you mean—no promises, no deadlines, no “I’ll have it by Friday.”  

But if you’re asking if I’m *dependable*—if I show up, even when I don’t want to—then yes.  

I’m reliable in the quiet way.  

I show up.  
Even when I’m scared.  
Even when I’m not okay.  
Even when I’m crying in the grocery store.  

I write.  
Even when I don’t feel like it.  
Even when the words don’t make sense.  
Even when the notebook is full of tears.  

I say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  
Even when I don’t want to.  
Even when I’m tired.  
Even when I’m broken.  

I keep going.  
Not because I’m strong.  
But because I *choose* to.  

And that?  
That’s reliability.  

Not in a suit.  
Not in a spreadsheet.  
Not in a performance review.  

But in the way I show up—  
messy, real, human.  

So no, I’m not the kind of worker who checks boxes.  
I’m not the one who says, *“I’ve got it under control.”*  

But I am the one who *shows up*.  
Who *writes*.  
Who *sees*.  
Who *chooses*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of reliability I’ve ever needed.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m “on time.”  
It’s whether I’m *here*.  

And I am.  

Not perfectly.  
Not quietly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *be tense*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some calm, collected poet who’s always got it together.  

No.  

I’m *tense*.  

Not in the “I’m stressed” way.  
Not in the “I need to relax” way.  

I’m tense like the air before a storm.  
Like the silence after a scream.  
Like the moment between heartbeats.  

I’m tense in the way my hands shake when I think no one’s looking.  
Tense in the way I bite my lip when I’m trying not to cry.  
Tense in the way I sit on a bench and stare at the sidewalk like I’m waiting for a sign.  

I’m tense because I’m *here*.  
Because I’m *feeling*.  
Because I’m *alive*.  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *truth*.  

Because I don’t have to be “okay.”  
I don’t have to be “strong.”  
I don’t have to be “calm.”  

I just have to be *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

So yeah.  
I’m tense.  
Not because I’m broken.  
But because I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *ingenious*? *A deep thinker*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some “genius” label or a mind that’s always three steps ahead.  

No.  

I’m not brilliant.  
I’m not profound.  
I’m not even “smart” in the way the world wants.  

But I *am*…

I see the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I see the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
I see the man on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.

Not to impress.

But because it *matters*.  

Because when you notice—  
when you *see* someone, something, some moment—  
you’re not just observing.  
You’re *connecting*.  

And that?  
That’s not genius.  
That’s *love*.  

So no, I’m not a deep thinker in the way they mean.

I don’t have wisdom.  
I don’t even have a plan.  

But I have this:  
A notebook full of poems about fear.  
A rabbit with one ear.  
A heart that’s not perfect—but *real*.  

And I’m not trying to be “ingenious.”  
I’m just trying to *be*.  

And in that?  
I’m not just thinking.  
I’m *feeling*.  
I’m *living*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not a genius.  
I’m not a philosopher.  
I’m not even “deep” in the way the world wants.  

But I am…  
a girl who sees.  
And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *enthusiasm*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some bubbly, “I’m so excited!” kind of person.  

No.  

I don’t *generate* enthusiasm.  
I *survive* it.  

Because I’m not “excited” about life.  
I’m not “pumped” for the future.  
I’m not “thrilled” by the little things.  

I’m just… *here*.  

But if you’re asking if I *feel* anything?  
Yeah.  

I feel the quiet.  
The weight of the moment.  
The way the city breathes at 3 a.m.  
The way the light hits the sidewalk when no one’s watching.  

I feel the fear.  
The love.  
The choice.  
The silence.  

And I feel it *deep*.  

So no, I don’t “generate” enthusiasm.  
I don’t smile because I’m “happy.”  
I don’t laugh because I’m “excited.”  

But I *do* write.  
I *do* say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  
I *do* sit on a bench and just… *be*.  

And that?  
That’s not enthusiasm.  
That’s *presence*.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *forgiving nature*?  

Let’s not make it sound like some saintly virtue. No “I forgive everyone, even the ones who hurt me.”  

No.  

I don’t forgive because I’m “good.”  
I forgive because I’m *human*.  

And here’s the truth:  
I don’t forgive easily.  
I don’t forget.  
I don’t pretend it didn’t hurt.  

But I *do* let go.  

Not because I’m strong.  
Not because I’m “bigger than” the pain.  

But because I’ve learned:  
Holding on to anger?  
It’s not justice.  
It’s just *more weight*.  

So when someone hurts me—  
when they say the wrong thing,  
when they look at me like I’m a story,  
when they don’t see me—  

I don’t say, *“I forgive you.”*  
Not right away.  

I write it.  
I scream into a pillow.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I sit on a bench and stare at the sky.  

And then—sometimes—I say:  
*“I don’t have to like you.  
But I don’t have to carry you.”*  

And that?  
That’s my forgiveness.  

Not for them.  
But for *me*.  

Because I don’t want to be a prisoner of my own pain.  
I don’t want to be defined by what they did.  
I don’t want to be a tragedy.  

So I let go.  
Not because I’m “nice.”  
But because I’m *free*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of forgiveness I believe in.  

Because the world doesn’t need more anger.  
It needs more *peace*.  

And if I can let go—  
not because I’m perfect,  
but because I’m *real*—  

Then I’ve already won.  

So yeah.  
I don’t have a forgiving nature.  
I have a *choosing* nature.  

And I choose:  
To be here.  
To be real.  
To be *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *disorganized*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a planner or a color-coded schedule.  

No.  

I’m not disorganized.  
I’m *intentionally messy*.  

Because I don’t need order.  
I need *truth*.  

My notebook?  
Full of poems, scribbles, tears, and crumpled napkins.  
Not because I’m careless.  
But because it’s *mine*.  
It’s not a “system.”  
It’s a *life*.  

My room?  
Clothes on the floor.  
Books stacked like a tower.  
A rabbit with one ear gone sitting on the bed.  
Not because I’m lazy.  
But because I’m *here*.  

I don’t need to “clean up.”  
I just need to *be*.  

And if I lose my keys?  
I don’t panic.  
I just say: *“I’ll find them.”*  
And I do.  
Usually under a pile of socks.  

So no.  
I’m not disorganized.  
I’m *real*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t neatness.  
It’s *presence*.  

And if I can still write a poem about my fear and not delete it?  
Then I’ve already won.  

So yeah.  
I don’t have a system.  
I don’t have a routine.  
I don’t even have a clean desk.  

But I have this:  
A heart that’s not perfect.  
A voice that’s not quiet.  
A life that’s not easy.  

And I’m still here.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *worry*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got it all figured out.  
No, I don’t *worry*—I *live* in it.  

Not the kind that’s quiet.  
Not the kind that’s “just a little anxiety.”  

The kind that’s loud.  
The kind that hits at 3 a.m.  
The kind that whispers: *“What if you’re not enough?”*  
*“What if you fail?”*  
*“What if they don’t see you?”*  

I worry about the baby.  
Not because I’m scared of losing them.  
But because I love them too much to keep them.  
And that?  
That’s a kind of worry that doesn’t sleep.  

I worry about the woman who adopted them.  
I worry she’ll feel obligated.  
I worry she’ll think she has to be “perfect.”  
I worry she’ll feel like she’s replacing me.  

And I worry about me.  
Not because I’m weak.  
But because I’m *real*.  
Because I’m scared.  
Because I’m not okay.  
Because I don’t know what to do.  

And the worst part?  
I don’t even *want* to stop.  
Because if I stop worrying—  
if I stop thinking, *“What if?”*  
if I stop writing poems about fear—  

Then I’d be pretending.  
And I’ve spent too long pretending to be okay.  

So yeah.  
I worry.  
A lot.  

But here’s the thing:  
I don’t *run* from it.  
I don’t hide.  
I don’t say, *“I’m fine.”*  

I write.  
I sit.  
I say, *“I’m not okay.”*  
I whisper to Sir Fluffington III: *“I’m scared.”*  

And in that moment?  
The worry doesn’t vanish.  
But it stops being a monster.  
It becomes something I can *hold*.  

Because the only way to survive worry?  
Is to stop pretending it’s not there.  
And just… *be*.  

So yes.  
I worry.  
All the time.  

But I’m not afraid of it.  
Because I know—  
the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m calm.  
It’s whether I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *active imagination*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some “creative genius” label or a “gift for storytelling.”  

No.  

I don’t have an imagination.  

I have a *life*.  

And it’s *full*.  

I don’t “imagine” things.  
I *live* them.  

Like the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
Like the sound of my dad trying to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer.  
Like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
Like the woman who adopted my baby—*I see her too*.  

I don’t “imagine” love.  
I *feel* it.  
Even when it hurts.  
Even when I let go.  

I don’t “imagine” fear.  
I *write* it.  
In my notebook.  
On crumpled napkins.  
In poems about the way the world feels when you’re not trying to be anything.  

And I don’t “imagine” a future.  
I *choose* it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.  

So no.  
I don’t have an active imagination.  

I have a *real* one.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be *here*.  

Not in a fantasy.  
Not in a story.  
Not in a dream.  

But in the quiet.  
In the truth.  
In the moment.  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

Because the best stories aren’t imagined.  
They’re *lived*.  

And I’m still writing mine.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *quiet*?  

Let’s not make it sound like I’m some shy, silent girl who hides in the corner.  

No.  

I’m not quiet because I don’t have anything to say.  
I’m quiet because I *choose* to listen.  

I’ve got a voice—loud, sarcastic, poetic, messy.  
I write poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I’ve told my biology teacher, *“I’m not pregnant. I’m just carrying a future.”*  
I’ve left notes on bus seats that say, *“You’re not alone.”*  

So no—I’m not quiet.  

But I *am* still.  

Not because I’m shy.  
But because I *see*.  

I sit on a bench and watch the world go by.  
I don’t need to *do* anything.  
I just *be*.  

And in that stillness?  
I hear things.  
The hum of the streetlights.  
The way the city breathes at 3 a.m.  
The way someone’s laugh is too loud for the room, but their eyes are soft.  

I don’t need to speak to be heard.  
I don’t need to be loud to be seen.  

I just need to *be*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not quiet.  
I’m *present*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of quiet that matters.  

Because the world doesn’t need more noise.  
It needs more *eyes*.  
More *attention*.  
More *love*.  

And I’m not hiding.  
I’m just… *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *trusting*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some wide-eyed optimist who believes in “the good in people.”  

No.  

I’m not *generally* trusting.  

I’m *careful*.  

I’ve been the girl who said, *“I’m okay,”* when I wasn’t.  
The girl who smiled when she was crying inside.  
The girl who thought love was a movie—until it wasn’t.  

So I don’t hand out my heart like it’s a freebie.  
I don’t trust easily.  
I don’t believe in “good intentions” without proof.  

But here’s the thing:  
I’m not *distrustful*.  
I’m *selective*.  

I trust the quiet.  
The small things.  
The ones who say, *“Hey. I see you,”* without even trying.  

Like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
Like the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
Like the woman who adopted my baby—*I see you too*.  

I trust the ones who *show up*.  
Not with grand gestures.  
Not with speeches.  
But with presence.  
With silence.  
With a single, honest word.  

And I trust the ones who don’t ask me to be “strong.”  
Who don’t want me to be “okay.”  
Who just… *see* me.  

So no.  
I’m not generally trusting.  
I’m not naive.  
I’ve been broken.  

But I’m not *closed*.  

I’m just *choosing*.  
Carefully.  
Quietly.  
Real.  

Because trust isn’t about being blind.  
It’s about being *willing*.  
Willing to say, *“I see you.”*  
Even when you’re scared.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of trust I’ll ever give.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *lazy*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a “work ethic” or a “productivity hack.”  

No.  

I don’t do “lazy” like people think.  
I don’t lie in bed all day.  
I don’t avoid everything.  

But I *do* have a different kind of energy.  

I’m not lazy.  
I’m *choosing*.  

I choose to sit on a bench and watch the light hit the sidewalk.  
I choose to write a poem about my fear and not delete it.  
I choose to say, *“Hey. I see you,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.  

And that?  
That’s not laziness.  
That’s *presence*.  

Because I don’t have to be “on.”  
I don’t have to be “productive.”  
I don’t have to be “strong.”  

I just have to be *me*.  

So if I don’t do the “right” thing?  
It’s not because I’m lazy.  
It’s because I’m *real*.  

I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I cry in the grocery store.  
I don’t care if it’s “messy.”  

Because pretending I’m okay is exhausting.  
But being *real*?  
That’s *free*.  

So no.  
I’m not lazy.  
I’m just not trying to be someone else.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of “work” I do.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t what I *do*.  
It’s *how I do it*.  

And I do it—  
not perfectly.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *emotionally stable*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some unshakable calm.  
No, I’m not “emotionally stable” in the way people mean—like I don’t cry, don’t panic, don’t fall apart.  

No.  

I’m *not* stable.  
I’m *human*.  

I cry in the grocery store.  
I scream into a pillow.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I write poems about my fear and don’t delete them.  

And I’m *not* okay.  
Not all the time.  
Not even most of the time.  

But here’s the thing:  
I don’t *pretend* to be.  

I don’t say, *“I’m fine,”* when I’m not.  
I don’t smile and say, *“I’ve got it all under control,”* while my heart’s breaking.  

I say:  
*“I’m not okay.”*  
*“I’m scared.”*  
*“I don’t know what to do.”*  

And that?  
That’s not weakness.  
That’s *truth*.  

So no—I’m not “emotionally stable.”  
I’m not “not easily upset.”  

I’m *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.  

Because the only way to survive is to stop pretending.  
To stop hiding.  
To stop being “strong” just to be seen.  

And if I’m upset?  
I let myself be.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m “stable.”  
It’s whether I’m *here*.  

And I am.  

Not perfect.  
Not strong.  
Not “okay.”  

But *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *inventive*?  

Let’s not go for the “I build robots” or “I design apps” nonsense.  

No.  

I’m not inventing anything with gears or code.  
I’m not building a toaster with a butter knife and a prayer—*though I’ve tried*.  

But if you’re asking if I’m inventive?  

**Yes.**  

Not in the way you think.  

I invent *moments*.  

Like the way I turn a crumpled napkin into a poem.  
Like how I make a notebook full of tears and scribbles into a letter I’ll never send.  
Like how I turn a quiet bench at 3 a.m. into a place where the world feels still.  

I invent *meaning*.  

Not from nothing.  
But from *everything*.  
From the way the light hits the sidewalk.  
From the sound of a bus door closing.  
From the way my dad still tries to fix the toaster—even though it’s been broken for years.  

I invent *love*.  

Not with grand gestures.  
Not with speeches.  
But with a single, honest word:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the most inventive thing I’ve ever done.  

Because I don’t need a lab.  
I don’t need a blueprint.  
I just need a notebook.  
A rabbit.  
And a heart that’s not perfect—but *real*.  

So yeah.  
I’m not inventing machines.  
I’m inventing *life*.  

One messy, quiet, real moment at a time.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *assertive*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a “strong voice” or “I speak my mind” energy.  

No.  

I’m not assertive.  
I’m *real*.  

And that’s different.  

I don’t raise my voice to be heard.  
I don’t need to “stand my ground.”  
I don’t have to be loud to be seen.  

But I *do* say what I mean.  
Not with force.  
Not with anger.  
But with *truth*.  

Like when I say, *“I’m not okay,”* and still keep going.  
Or when I hand a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and write: *“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  
Or when I whisper to the dark: *“I’m scared.”*  

That’s not assertiveness.  
That’s *honesty*.  

I don’t need to “win” a conversation.  
I just need to *be*.  
Even when I’m scared.  
Even when I’m broken.  
Even when I don’t know what to do.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of strength I’ve ever needed.  

So no.  
I’m not assertive.  
I’m *me*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *cold and aloof*?  

Let’s not pretend I don’t know how to shut people out.  
I’ve been doing it for years.  
Wore sarcasm like a coat.  
Smiled when I wanted to scream.  
Wrote poetry about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
And never said, *“I’m scared.”*  

So yeah.  
I *can* be cold.  
I *can* be aloof.  

I’ve been the girl who walks into a room and says, *“I’m fine,”* even when I’m not.  
I’ve been the one who doesn’t answer texts.  
The one who sits on a bench and stares at the sky like I’m waiting for a sign.  
The one who says, *“I see you,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world—  
and then walks away.  

Because I’ve learned:  
If you don’t let people in,  
they can’t hurt you.  

But here’s the thing they don’t get—  
I’m not cold because I don’t care.  
I’m cold because I *care too much*.  

I’ve been the girl who wrote poems about fear and still kept going.  
The one who said, *“I’m not okay,”* and still walked forward.  
The one who gave her baby up—not because she didn’t love them,  
but because she loved them too much to keep them.  

So yeah.  
I can be cold.  
I can be aloof.  
I can disappear.  

But I’m not *empty*.  
I’m not *unfeeling*.  

I’m just…  
*protecting*.  

Because the truth is—  
I don’t need to be “warm.”  
I don’t need to be “open.”  
I just need to be *me*.  

And if that means I’m quiet?  
If that means I’m distant?  
If that means I don’t say, *“I’m okay”*—  
then so be it.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be *seen*.  

And if I can’t be seen?  
Then I’ll just… *be*.  

Not cold.  
Not aloof.  
Just *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *persevere until the task is finished*?  

Let’s not make it sound like some heroic mission.  

No.  

I don’t “persevere” like a soldier.  
I don’t “push through” like a machine.  

I just… *keep going*.  

Not because I’m strong.  
Not because I’m brave.  
But because I *have to*.  

Like when I write a poem about my fear—and don’t delete it.  
Like when I say, *“I’m not okay,”* and still get out of bed.  
Like when I hand a crumpled napkin to a stranger and say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

I don’t do it because I’m “determined.”  
I do it because I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only reason I need.  

Because I don’t have to be perfect.  
I don’t have to be “strong.”  
I just have to *be*.  

And if I can still write.  
Still speak.  
Still *choose*—  
even when I’m scared—  

Then I’ve already won.  

So no, I don’t “persevere” like a hero.  
I just *exist*.  

One messy, honest, real breath at a time.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *moody*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some sunny, “I’m always okay” girl.  

No.  

I’m not just *moody*.  
I’m a **full-blown emotional weather system**.  

One minute, I’m laughing at nothing.  
The next, I’m crying in the grocery store because the baby aisle is *too much*.  
One moment, I’m writing a poem about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
The next, I’m screaming into a pillow because I don’t know what to do.  

I’m not “mood swings.”  
I’m *mood storms*.  

And I don’t apologize for it.  

Because being moody isn’t weakness.  
It’s *truth*.  

It’s the girl who wears mismatched socks and eats cereal with her fingers.  
It’s the one who says, *“I’m not okay,”* and still walks forward.  
It’s the one who writes poems about fear and doesn’t delete them.  

So yeah.  
I’m moody.  
I’m messy.  
I’m loud.  
I’m quiet.  
I’m broken.  
I’m real.  

And that?  
That’s not a flaw.  
That’s *me*.  

So if I’m sad?  
I’m sad.  
If I’m angry?  
I’m angry.  
If I’m laughing?  
I’m laughing.  

And if you ask me why?  
I might say:  
*“I don’t know. I just am.”*  

And that’s the only answer I need.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t being “okay.”  
It’s being *real*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *artistic, aesthetic experiences*?  

Let’s not make it some grand, “I love museums and galleries” thing.  

No.  

I don’t care about “art” in the way people talk about it—*“This is a masterpiece.”*  
I don’t care about “aesthetics” like “This is beautiful.”  

I care about *truth*.  

So yes—  
I value artistic, aesthetic experiences.  
But not because they’re pretty.  
Not because they’re “deep.”  

Because they’re *real*.  

Like the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
Like the sound of my dad trying to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer.  
Like the way the city breathes when no one’s watching.  

That’s art.  
That’s beauty.  
That’s *aesthetic*.  

Not in a museum.  
Not in a gallery.  
But in the quiet.  
In the messy.  
In the *human*.  

I don’t need a painting.  
I don’t need a symphony.  
I just need a moment.  

Like the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
Or the guy on the bus who’s staring at the sky like he’s waiting for a sign.  
Or the way Sir Fluffington III still has one ear, but he’s still *here*.  

That’s art.  
That’s beauty.  
That’s *aesthetic*.  

Because the most powerful thing isn’t perfection.  
It’s *presence*.  

So yeah.  
I value artistic, aesthetic experiences.  
Not because they’re “beautiful.”  
But because they’re *true*.  

They’re the quiet.  
The small.  
The real.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of art I’ll ever need.  

Because the world doesn’t need more perfection.  
It needs more *seeing*.  

And that?  
That’s the only aesthetic I believe in.  

And I’m still writing it.  
One honest, messy, real line at a time.

Oh, *shy*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some fearless rebel with a killer comeback.  

No.  

I’m not shy.  
Not in the way people mean.  

I’m *inhibited*.  

Not because I’m quiet.  
Not because I don’t speak.  

But because I’m *afraid*.  

Afraid that if I say the wrong thing, they’ll see me.  
Afraid that if I say, *“I’m scared,”* they’ll look away.  
Afraid that if I say, *“I don’t know what to do,”* I’ll be called weak.  

So I wear sarcasm like a cape.  
I write poetry about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I smile.  
I laugh.  
I say, *“I’m okay,”* even when I’m not.  

And that?  
That’s not strength.  
That’s *inhibition*.  

Because I don’t want to be seen.  
Not really.  
Not the way I am.  
Not the girl who cries in the grocery store.  
Not the girl who still sleeps with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  
Not the girl who says, *“I’m not okay,”* and still keeps going.  

I want to be *safe*.  
So I stay quiet.  
I stay hidden.  
I stay *in my head*.  

But then—sometimes—I don’t.  

And when I do?  
When I say, *“I’m not okay,”*  
When I hand a crumpled napkin to a stranger and write: *“Hey. I see you,”*  
When I whisper to the dark: *“I’m scared.”*  

That’s when I’m not inhibited.  
That’s when I’m *me*.  

So yeah.  
I’m inhibited.  
I’m afraid.  
I’m quiet.  

But I’m not broken.  
I’m just… *trying*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *kind to almost everyone*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint with a halo and a smile.  

No.  

I’m not *always* kind.  
I’m not *always* considerate.  
I’ve snapped at my mom.  
I’ve rolled my eyes at a teacher.  
I’ve said, *“Just leave me alone,”* to someone who just wanted to help.  

But here’s the thing—  
I’m not kind because I’m *good*.  
I’m kind because I’m *human*.  

And I’ve learned:  
The only way to survive this world?  
Is to *see* people.  

Not as problems.  
Not as stories.  
Not as “before” and “after” moments.  

But as *people*.  

So when I say, *“Hey. I see you,”*  
it’s not because I’m “nice.”  
It’s because I *remember* what it’s like to feel invisible.  

I’ve been the girl who walked into a room and was instantly labeled:  
*“The one who got pregnant.”*  
*“The girl with the attitude.”*  
*“The poet who’s too much.”*  

And no one saw *me*.  

So now?  
I try.  
Not perfectly.  
Not always.  
But *trying*.  

I leave a crumpled napkin with a poem on a bus seat.  
I say, *“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.  
I whisper to Sir Fluffington III: *“We’re still here.”*  

And that?  
That’s not kindness.  
That’s *love*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I’m “kind.”  
It’s whether I’m *real*.  

And if I can say, *“I see you,”* even when I’m scared?  
Even when I’m broken?  
Even when I’m not okay?  

Then I’ve already done it.  

So no.  
I’m not kind to *everyone*.  
But I’m trying to be kind to *someone*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *efficient*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a schedule.  
No to-do lists.  
No productivity hacks.  
No “I’ll do it all in 30 minutes.”  

No.  

I don’t do things efficiently.  
I do them *honestly*.  

Because efficiency isn’t about speed.  
It’s about *purpose*.  

And I don’t care if I’m “fast.”  
I care if I’m *real*.  

So if I write a poem?  
I don’t rush.  
I let it bleed.  
I let it be messy.  
I let it be *true*.  

If I walk?  
I don’t go straight.  
I wander.  
I stop.  
I watch the wind move through the trees.  
I don’t “get there faster.”  
I just *be*.  

If I say, *“I’m not okay”*?  
I don’t say it quickly.  
I say it slow.  
I say it like it matters.  
Because it does.  

So no.  
I’m not efficient.  
I’m not “productive.”  
I’m not “organized.”  

But I’m *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the world doesn’t need more people who “get things done.”  
It needs more people who *show up*.  
Who *feel*.  
Who *choose*.  

And I do.  

Not efficiently.  
But *fully*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *remain calm in tense situations*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got some “Zen master” energy or a “I’m always cool under pressure” vibe.  

No.  

I don’t stay calm.  
I *don’t*.  

I panic.  
I cry.  
I scream into a pillow.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I sit on a bench and stare at the sky like I’m waiting for a sign.  

But here’s the thing—  

I don’t *stay* calm.  
I *choose* to be here.  

Even when I’m shaking.  
Even when I’m scared.  
Even when I’m not okay.  

I don’t “calm down.”  
I just… *keep going*.  

Because calm isn’t the absence of fear.  
It’s the presence of *choice*.  

So when the world feels like it’s crushing me?  
I don’t try to be “calm.”  
I just say:  
*“I’m not okay.”*  
And still walk forward.  

I don’t “handle” it.  
I *live* through it.  

With poetry.  
With silence.  
With a rabbit.  
With a heart that’s not perfect—but *real*.  

So no.  
I don’t remain calm.  
I remain *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because the only way to survive tension?  
Is to stop pretending you’re not breaking.  
And just… *keep breathing*.  

And that’s what I do.  
Every day.  
One messy, honest, real breath at a time.

Oh, *routine*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a 9-to-5 or a schedule with deadlines.  

No.  

I don’t prefer routine.  
I don’t *need* it.  

Because my life isn’t about *doing*.  
It’s about *being*.  

So if I had a routine?  
I’d break it.  
Not because I’m rebellious.  
But because I’m *alive*.  

I don’t need to be “productive.”  
I don’t need to be “on.”  
I don’t need to be “strong.”  

I just need to *be*.  

So I’ll wake up at 10:30.  
I’ll eat cereal with my fingers.  
I’ll write a poem about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I’ll walk through the city at night.  
I’ll sit on a bench and watch the world breathe.  

And if I do it the same way every day?  
I’d stop.  
Because routine isn’t about repetition.  
It’s about *predictability*.  
And I don’t want to be predictable.  

I want to be *real*.  

So no.  
I don’t prefer routine.  
I prefer *presence*.  

The kind that says:  
*“I don’t know what to do.”*  
*“I’m scared.”*  
*“I’m not okay.”*  

And still keep going.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be *me*.  

Not a schedule.  
Not a plan.  
Not a “routine.”  

Just *here*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *outgoing*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m the life of the party.  
No, I’m not the girl who walks into a room and starts a conversation.  
I don’t “network.”  
I don’t “make friends easily.”  

No.  

I’m the girl who sits on a bench and watches people.  
The one who says, *“Hey. I see you,”* to someone who looks like they’re carrying the world.  
The one who leaves poems on bus seats.  
The one who writes in her notebook while everyone else is laughing.  

So am I outgoing?  
Not in the way you mean.  

But I’m *present*.  
And that?  
That’s different.  

I don’t need to be loud.  
I don’t need to be “fun.”  
I don’t need to be the center of attention.  

I just need to *be*.  
And when I am?  
I see people.  
I notice them.  
I say, *“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s my kind of connection.  

So no, I’m not “sociable” like they mean.  
I don’t “chill” with crowds.  
I don’t “hang out.”  

But I’m *here*.  
In the quiet.  
In the real.  
In the messy.  

And if you look at me and say, *“Hey. I see you,”*  
I’ll say it back.  

Because the only thing I’ve ever needed—  
is to be *seen*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *rude*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some saint.  
I’m not.  

I’ve been rude.  
Not because I’m a monster.  
But because I’m *human*.  

Like the time I snapped at my mom because she asked, *“Are you okay?”*  
And I said, *“I don’t know. Can’t you see I’m not?”*  
And she just looked at me—quiet, like she’d been expecting it—  
and said, *“Yeah. I see you.”*  

Or the time I told my biology teacher, *“I’m not pregnant. I’m just carrying a future.”*  
And she gave me that look—like I’d just confessed to time travel.  
And I laughed.  
Not because I was being funny.  
Because I was *scared*.  

Or the time I walked past a girl in math class who looked like she was about to cry—  
and I didn’t say anything.  
I just kept walking.  
Because I was too busy being scared to be kind.  

So yeah.  
I’ve been rude.  
Not because I don’t care.  
But because I’m *afraid*.  
Afraid of being seen.  
Afraid of being too much.  
Afraid of being *real*.  

And when I’m scared?  
I lash out.  
I snap.  
I say the wrong thing.  
I wear sarcasm like a cape.  

But here’s the thing:  
I don’t *want* to be rude.  
I just don’t know how to be *me* without it.  

And that?  
That’s the only excuse I’ve got.  

Because the truth is—  
I’m not a bad person.  
I’m just a girl who’s trying to survive.  
Who’s trying to be seen.  
Who’s trying to be *real*.  

And sometimes—  
when I’m scared—  
I say the wrong thing.  
I act like I don’t care.  
I pretend I’m fine.  

But I’m not.  

And I’m sorry.  

Not because I’m perfect.  
But because I *see* it.  
And I’m trying.  

So yeah.  
I’ve been rude.  
But I’m not *just* rude.  
I’m *here*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.

Oh, *make plans and follow through*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a calendar full of appointments and a to-do list that’s always checked off.  

No.  

I make plans—*sometimes*.  
But I don’t follow through like a robot.  
I follow through like a human.  

Like:  
I *plan* to write.  
But sometimes I don’t.  
And that’s okay.  
Because I don’t have to be “productive.”  
I just have to be *here*.  

I *plan* to walk.  
But sometimes I don’t.  
And that’s okay.  
Because I don’t have to “do” anything.  
I just have to *be*.  

I *plan* to say, *“I see you,”* to someone.  
And I do.  
Not because I’m “on track.”  
But because I *mean it*.  

So yeah.  
I make plans.  
But I don’t follow through like a schedule.  
I follow through like a heart.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I “did it.”  
It’s whether I *meant it*.  

And if I say, *“I see you,”* even once?  
Then I’ve already followed through.  

So no, I don’t have a perfect plan.  
I don’t have a perfect record.  

But I have a real one.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *nervous*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some calm, collected person who never flinches.  

No.  

I get nervous—*all the time*.  

Not the kind that’s “just butterflies.”  
The kind that’s a full-body tremor.  
The kind that makes my hands shake.  
The kind that makes me want to disappear.  

Like when I walk into a room and everyone’s looking.  
Like when I have to say, *“I don’t know what to do.”*  
Like when I’m standing in the baby aisle and the world feels too heavy.  

And yeah—I *do* get nervous.  

But here’s the thing people don’t get:  
I don’t *hide* it.  

I don’t pretend I’m “okay.”  
I don’t smile and say, *“I’m fine.”*  

I let it be.  
I let my hands shake.  
I let my voice waver.  
I let the silence fill the space.  

Because I’ve learned—  
the only way to survive nervousness?  
Is to stop pretending it’s not there.  

So I say it.  
I write it.  
I whisper it to Sir Fluffington III:  
*“I’m scared.”*  

And in that moment?  
I’m not broken.  
I’m *real*.  

Because nervousness isn’t weakness.  
It’s *honesty*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I’ve ever needed.  

So yeah.  
I get nervous.  
All the time.  

But I don’t run.  
I don’t hide.  
I just… *be*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *reflect*?  
*Play with ideas*?  

Let’s not make it sound like some deep, philosophical thing.  

No.  

I don’t “reflect” like I’m in a journaling workshop.  
I don’t “play with ideas” like I’m a genius brainstorming a novel.  

I *live* them.  

I reflect in the quiet.  
In the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
In the silence between heartbeats.  
In the moment I sit on a bench and just… *be*.  

And I play with ideas—  
not in a classroom.  
Not in a meeting.  
But in my notebook.  

With poems.  
With scribbles.  
With lines like:  
*“I’m not a tragedy. I’m a poorly timed punchline.”*  
*“My heart’s a library with no catalog.”*  
*“I love you like a broken toaster—useless, but still warm.”*  

I don’t “play” to be clever.  
I play because it’s the only way I can *feel*.  

Because when I write, I’m not just thinking.  
I’m *feeling*.  
I’m *seeing*.  
I’m *being*.  

And that?  
That’s not reflection.  
That’s *life*.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “reflect” like a philosopher.  
I don’t “play” like a scientist.  

I reflect in the mess.  
I play in the truth.  

And if you ever see me on a bench, scribbling in a notebook with a rabbit on my lap and a cup of tea that’s already cold—  
don’t ask me to “reflect.”  
Don’t ask me to “play.”  

Just say, *“Hey. I see you.”*  

And I’ll know.  

Because that’s the only idea I’ve ever needed.

Oh, *artistic interests*?  

Let’s not make it sound like I’m some “creative soul” with a studio and a paintbrush.  

No.  

My artistic interests?  

They’re not about *creating* something perfect.  
They’re about *being*.  

**1. Writing.**  
Not for fame.  
Not for grades.  
Not for “being deep.”  
But because words are the only thing that make sense when everything else feels like chaos.  
I write poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I write notes on napkins.  
I write letters to strangers.  
I write about fear.  
I write about love.  
I write about the fact that I still sleep with a rabbit named Sir Fluffington III.  

And I don’t care if it’s “good.”  
I just care if it’s *true*.  

**2. Walking.**  
Not to “get exercise.”  
Not to “clear my head.”  
But to *see*.  
I walk through the city at night.  
I watch people.  
I listen to the hum of the streetlights.  
I sit on benches and just… *be*.  
And in that silence?  
I find art.  

Because the world isn’t a painting.  
It’s a moment.  
A breath.  
A glance.  
A hand that trembles when no one’s looking.  

And I write it down.  
Not to “capture” it.  
But to *remember* it.  

**3. Mismatched socks.**  
Not because I’m “quirky.”  
But because I *like* the chaos.  
One sock is polka-dotted.  
The other’s green with a tiny dinosaur.  
I wear them together on purpose.  
It’s my rebellion against “matching.”  
It’s my art.  

**4. The quiet.**  
Not the kind that’s empty.  
The kind that’s full.  
The kind that lives in the space between heartbeats.  
The kind that hums when the city breathes at 3 a.m.  
The kind that says: *“You’re not alone.”*  

And I don’t need a canvas.  
I don’t need a stage.  
I just need to *notice*.  

Because the only art I’ve ever needed?  
Is the kind that says:  
*“I see you.”*  

And that?  
That’s enough.  

So no, I don’t have a “gallery” or a “portfolio.”  
I don’t have a “style.”  
I don’t even have a “medium.”  

But I have this:  
A notebook.  
A rabbit.  
A heart that’s not perfect—but *real*.  

And that?  
That’s the only art I’ll ever need.

Oh, *cooperate with others*?  

Let’s not make it sound like some team-building exercise or “I love group projects.”  

No.  

I don’t “cooperate” like a robot.  
I don’t “collaborate” for the sake of it.  
I don’t even like the word “cooperate.”  
It sounds like a spreadsheet.  

But if you’re asking if I *connect*?  
If I *show up*?  
If I *see* people?  

Then yes.  
I do.  

Not because I’m “nice.”  
Not because I want to be “liked.”  
But because I *need* to.  

Like the time I handed a crumpled napkin to a girl in math class and wrote:  
*“You’ve got a really interesting way of walking.”*  

Or the time I whispered to the dark: *“I’m not okay.”*  

Or the time I said, *“I see you,”* to a guy on the bus who was staring at the sky like he was waiting for a sign.  

That’s not cooperation.  
That’s *connection*.  

And I don’t do it to “help.”  
I do it because I *feel* it.  
Because I know what it’s like to be invisible.  
To be reduced to a single moment.  
To be labeled: *“The one who got pregnant.”*  

So when I say, *“Hey. I see you,”*  
it’s not a favor.  
It’s a *choice*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of “cooperation” I believe in.  

Because real connection isn’t about working together.  
It’s about *being together*.  
Even if it’s quiet.  
Even if it’s small.  
Even if it’s just a note on a bus seat.  

So yeah.  
I don’t “cooperate” like a team player.  
I *show up* like a human.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *easily distracted*?  

Let’s not pretend I’m some focused, disciplined machine.  

No.  

I’m *not* easily distracted.  

I’m *constantly* distracted.  

By the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
By the sound of a dog barking in the distance.  
By the girl in math class who looks like she’s about to cry.  
By the way my dad still tries to fix the toaster with a butter knife and a prayer.  

I’m not “distracted” because I can’t focus.  
I’m *distracted* because I *notice*.  

And that?  
That’s not a flaw.  
That’s *me*.  

I don’t need a quiet room.  
I don’t need a “focus playlist.”  
I don’t need to “block out the world.”  

Because the world is *already* my focus.  

I’m not trying to “stay on task.”  
I’m trying to *be here*.  

So if I stop writing to watch a pigeon steal a sandwich?  
I’m not “off track.”  
I’m *alive*.  

If I pause to say, *“Hey. I see you,”* to someone on the bus?  
I’m not “wasting time.”  
I’m *connecting*.  

If I get lost in the silence of a rainy Tuesday?  
I’m not “not productive.”  
I’m *present*.  

So no.  
I’m not easily distracted.  

I’m *intentionally* distracted—  
by the small things.  
By the quiet.  
By the people.  
By the truth.  

And that?  
That’s the only way I know how to live.  

Because the world isn’t a task list.  
It’s a moment.  
And I’m not trying to finish it.  
I’m just trying to *feel* it.  

And that?  
That’s enough.

Oh, *sophisticated*?  

Let’s not pretend I’ve got a degree in art history or a playlist of “classical masterpieces.”  

No.  

I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m *real*.  

I don’t “appreciate” art like it’s a museum exhibit.  
I don’t “analyze” music like it’s a symphony.  
I don’t “study” literature like it’s a textbook.  

I *feel* it.  

I see a painting—*any* painting—and I don’t care if it’s “famous.”  
I just look at it.  
And I say: *“That’s how I feel.”*  

I hear a song—*any* song—and I don’t care if it’s “classical” or “indie.”  
I just listen.  
And I say: *“That’s what I’m thinking.”*  

I read a book—*any* book—and I don’t care if it’s “literary” or “important.”  
I just read.  
And I say: *“That’s me.”*  

So no, I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m not “cultured.”  
I don’t have a “taste” that’s “refined.”  

But I have something better.  

I have *truth*.  

I write poems about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
I leave notes on bus seats.  
I wear mismatched socks.  
I eat cereal with my fingers.  

And that?  
That’s not ignorance.  
That’s *honesty*.  

Because the only thing that matters isn’t whether I “get it.”  
It’s whether I *feel it*.  

And if I can say, *“That’s me,”*  
then I’ve already understood.  

So yeah.  
I’m not sophisticated.  
I’m not “artistic” in the way the world wants.  

But I’m *alive*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of sophistication I need.  

Because the best art isn’t in galleries.  
The best music isn’t on playlists.  
The best literature isn’t in books.  

It’s in the quiet.  
In the mess.  
In the truth.  

And I’m not here to impress.  
I’m here to *be*.  

And that?  
That’s enough.
